reviewText: I bought this cause my mom saw it and said she wanted it. I got it and she loves it.  Makes her remember her childhood!

reviewText: I've been on a roll lately trying to find as many Charlie Chan DVD's as I can.  I just love the "old-timey" black and white mysteries but I was totally surprised that there had ever been a television series.  I do like it but the transfer is not the best which is noted at the beginning of the discs but they are certainly watchable half hour mysteries.  I'm not sorry I purchased this at all.
summary: An Interesting Take on Charlie Chan

reviewText: Having recently gotten on a nostalgic Charlie Chan kick, I was glad to get these episodes of the television series of the 50's.  Although the film quality is not the best, due to the age and lack of preservation, I have not found this to be a problem in enjoying these half hour mysteries.

reviewText: I received this item today and found that my DVD players (9 of them) and 2 computers can not read the disks.  The only way I was able to watch was on a portable DVD player which is rather inconvenient.  So, buyer beware!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'd written a review on this set and mistakenly submitted it under the Roland Winters Chan film, The Golden Eye, which is not bad if you can accept Winters as Chan (if you don't know the name, he played Elvis' father in Blue Hawaii, and appeared in many other films, yet he will now be known as the 3rd Chan for me).In brief, this J Carrol Nash boxed set of 30minute TV shows from the mid to late 50s was a very pleasing surprise, and I only wish there were more.  Nash's version of Chan may take a little getting used to, but he does a very good job considering the handicap of a 30 minute programs and the cheap productions.  James Hong - still with us - plays #1 son, but for some reason he is named "Berry."  If you are a true Chan enthusiast, you should add this set to your collection (Don't waste your time with the Peter Ustinov insult to Chan even though he did a pleasing interpretation of Poirot in several features)J Carrol Nash could have successfully continued the Chan franchise on the theater screen if he were allowed to grow into the character as he'd done in other roles, from General Sheridan for John Ford, to his many bad-guy roles, and would have been at least as good as Sidney Toler and better than Roland Winters.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I never knew this one existed. It was great and my grandaughter and I loved it. It will be another one to watch again on a nice rainy day with some of the grand kids. great old movies are really hard to find.Pretty soon they will want to be remaking these old movies again.

reviewText: The video quality is very poor and difficult to watch. If you are a Charlie Chan movie fan you will probably be disappointed with this TV series. No humor and no Chinese proverbs either. We have watched 2 episodes and not likely to watch the rest.
summary: We love the Charlie Chan movies but this is not good.
